Issues.Title: Implement IDisposable in ThreadMethodEntry class
Issues.Body:
### Background and motivation

[ThreadMethodEntry](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/d20f9c71a189693c6c3475253397665bce0a1354/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/Control.ThreadMethodEntry.cs#L11) class have a Finalizer but not implement an `IDisposable` interface. So, after **every** call to `BeginInvoke`/`Invoke` instance of `ThreadMethodEntry` will end up in Freachable queue:
![Snipaste_2023-11-22_14-23-10](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/17767561/18e44560-5e00-4c90-a447-36f2f1faf1aa)

Finalizer here to free WH:
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/d20f9c71a189693c6c3475253397665bce0a1354/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/Control.ThreadMethodEntry.cs#L51-L54
We have 3 cases here (for all of them `ThreadMethodEntry` will end up in Freachable queue any way) :
- We not allocate WH.
- We allocate WH and use it internally (`Invoke`) - we not free it. This already violate `IAsyncResult.AsyncWaitHandle` [using rules](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.iasyncresult.asyncwaithandle?view=net-8.0#notes-to-callers).
- User allocate WH through `IAsyncResult.AsyncWaitHandle` (`BeginInvoke`). And even if he properly Close this WH, `ThreadMethodEntry` will end up in Freachable queue :(

### Proposal

Suggestions:
- implement `IDisposable`.
- register for finalization only when WH is allocated.
- SuppressFinalize after WH disposed.

If you don't mind in principle, you can assignee this to me. I have some ideas on this matter, and will try to implement them as soon as find time.

### Risks

Must be minimal...

### Will this feature affect UI controls?

No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Implement IDisposable in ThreadMethodEntry class" (#10361)

Issues.Title: `Curosor.Draw` draws with broken alpha channel
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

7.0.400

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

_No response_

### Issue description

`Curosor.Draw` draws with broken alpha channel:
Result:
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/1285934/727ae1e1-a75f-44fd-95bd-257b97ae75dc)
Expected:
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/1285934/d4cd08e0-79b5-4ba3-95b5-942993deddec)

Also reported here more that 10 years ago: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4451839/how-to-render-a-transparent-cursor-to-bitmap-preserving-alpha-channel

### Steps to reproduce

```cs
Cursor cursor = Cursors.AppStarting;
Bitmap bitmap = new Bitmap(cursor.Size.Width, cursor.Size.Height, PixelFormat.Format32bppArgb);
Graphics g = Graphics.FromImage(bitmap);
cursor.Draw(g, new Rectangle(0, 0, bitmap.Width, bitmap.Height));
bitmap.Save(Path.Combine(Directory.GetCurrentDirectory(), "cursor.png"), ImageFormat.Png);
```

This code with `Icon.ToBitmap` works as expected:
```cs
Cursor cursor = Cursors.AppStarting;
Icon.FromHandle((IntPtr)cursor.Handle).ToBitmap().Save(Path.Combine(Directory.GetCurrentDirectory(), $"cursor.png"), ImageFormat.Png);
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "`Curosor.Draw` draws with broken alpha channel" (#10360)

Issues.Title: FolderBrowseDialog: Unexpected Positioning and Incorrect BackgroundColor of Description
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

8.0.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

_No response_

### Issue description

When setting the `Description` property of a `FolderBrowseDialog` instance, the configured description is displayed at an unexpected position and with an incorrect `BackgroundColor`.

**Example:**
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/5320760/b3d8b1b4-7224-4ce7-b769-4bd8166682f1)
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/5320760/3f6a247f-7e53-43f6-96ce-9e264d35c267)

### Steps to reproduce

```csharp
using(FolderBrowserDialog dialog = new FolderBrowserDialog())
{
    dialog.Description = "Test123";
    dialog.ShowDialog();
}
```

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] Select ListView item with mouse, Narrator can't select whole rows
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

9.0.100-alpha.1.23564.26

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No, this issue also repro's on .NET 6.0/7.0/8.0.

### Issue description

Narrator does not select the entire row when the ListView item is selected with the mouse, but it selects the entire row when it is selected with the keyboard.
**The behavior for .NET 9.0:**
![core](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/104609169/bc2b9f4c-6ffa-4f92-a119-be1d811de93c)

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/104609169/6ffed828-685c-44fc-aef0-0b501df4bb44

**The behavior for .Net framework:**
![framework](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/104609169/f6cb5ea1-2f41-40cd-ada7-cc548ba848dc)

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/104609169/1a4ed23d-a388-4457-a458-0e0f360c83ce




### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a WinForms .NET Core application with ListView control.
2. Add some columns and items to it and set the checkbox property to true.
3. Set ListView's View as Details.
4. Build and run the application.
5. Launch the Narrator tool, try to focus on the item of ListView with mouse.
6. Press up/down keyboard to focus on the other item.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility] Select ListView item with mouse, Narrator can't select whole rows" (#10355)

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] After selecting ListView item with mouse and then space selected, Narrator can't display and read out the current status
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

9.0.100-alpha.1.23564.26

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No, this issue also repro's on .NET 6.0/7.0/8.0.

### Issue description

Narrator can't display and read out the current state of a ListView item when it is selected with mouse and then space-selected, but Narrator can display and read out the current state of a ListView item when it is selected with keyboard and then space-selected.

**The behavior for .NET 9.0:**
![space](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/104609169/a9be8f4d-78da-4351-9858-34bf407bde27)

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/104609169/1ca4e6aa-217f-4408-9ba5-2f8de046e3a0

**The behavior for .Net framework:**
![framework](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/104609169/2348b3cd-b904-43ed-96d2-c61d227a97f1)


https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/104609169/8c58afaa-f865-42b3-8664-1f5dd76dbe36



### Steps to reproduce
[WinFormsApp28.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/13435385/WinFormsApp28.zip)


1. Create a WinForms .NET Core application with ListView control.
2. Add some columns and items to it and set the checkbox property to true.
3. Set ListView's View as Details.
4. Build and run the application.
5. Launch the Narrator tool, try to focus on the first item of the ListView with the mouse.
6. Type the space bar.
7. Press up/down keyboard to focus on the next item.
8. Type the space bar.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility] After selecting ListView item with mouse and then space selected, Narrator can't display and read out the current status" (#10354)

Issues.Title: Convert Rest of IRawElementProviderX to Cswin32
Issues.Body:
Converts `IRawElementProviderFragmentRoot` and `IRawElementProviderHwndOverride` to Cswin32. Each conversion is separated into its own commit.  Note that we do not currently return anything from `IRawElementProviderHwndOverride.GetOverrideProviderForHwnd` aside from null so I've added a commit to remove the corresponding virtual method in separate commit.

Tested manually with Narrator and AccessibilityInsights.

Issues.Title: Re-occurrence of WinForms designer failing to load
Issues.Body:
### Environment

Visual Studio Version 17.8.0

### .NET version

8.0.0

### Did this work in a previous version of Visual Studio and/or previous .NET release?

I have had this issue in the past under .NET 5 & 6 as per https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/6492

However, .NET 8 has been working just fine since converting a project to 8 several weeks ago. I have been working on this project non stop for weeks, until this occurred just now.

### Issue description

Exactly as per closed issue https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/6492

I have been working on this project for weeks, with minor occurrences of behaviour I have witness across multiple machines, and multiple VS versions for years - where jumping between code/designer views, often the designer tab will actually display the code, and closing/reloading the designer view resolves the issue.

However, loading the project this morning I am unable to open the design. VS and the machine were shut down correctly, and nobody else has touched this (all files saved locally).

### Steps to reproduce

Unfortunately I have no idea how to reproduce the issue, as it has just re-occurred seemingly out of nowhere. In my case, it occurred loading the project again this morning, having been working on it for weeks.

I have attempted to generate logs by following https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/6492#issuecomment-1010310024 but absolutely nothing is generated.

I can open a different solution (.NET 6), and the designer loads just fine.

Now, most interesting - I've closing that other solution, jumped back to the problematic solution, and the designer now loads just fine? Even though before I've closed and re-opened the solution, and VS< and the machine several times. Now that he designer has loaded, the log contains many entries.

### Diagnostics

_No response_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Re-occurrence of WinForms designer failing to load" (#10352)

Issues.Title: The default value of bindSource.SortDesciptions has been changed
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 9.0 main branch

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, it works in .NET 6.0/7.0/8.0. **Regression from: https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10253, this affects our automation test cases.**

### Issue description

.NET 9.0:
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/86937911/6042b1eb-acc9-457b-b323-fc5f7c9fef82)
.NET 8.0:
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/86937911/246234b7-f345-4ebb-aa6c-0ab4ddb2380e)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a WinForms .NET Core project with a BindingSource.
2. Double click Form1 and type below code in `Form1_Load` event:
`bindingSource1.DataSource = new string[] { "a", "b", "c" };`
3. Add a breakpoint to the event, build and run the application.
4. Check the value of bindindSource.SortDesciptions.

Issues.Title: Move && and || to front of lines
Issues.Body:
This changes some of the code (primarily DataGrid) to match the desired code style with line breaking on long logical statements.

To align conceptually the logical operators should be at the beginning of the line when breaking long statements.

When considering how to break lines, logical conditions grouped by a specific set of parentheses should either all be broken out into separate lines or kept together on a single line. To show nesting, statements should be indented to match the parenthetical nesting, but parentheses should not get their own line.

Some examples:

``` C#
if (_trackColumn != previousColumnIndex
    && !(previousColumnIndex == -1 && hti._col == _trackColumn)
    && (dataGridViewColumnNext is null || _trackColumn != dataGridViewColumnNext.Index))
```

And:

``` C#
if (Focused
    && !IsCurrentCellInEditMode
    && (EditMode == DataGridViewEditMode.EditOnEnter
        || (EditMode != DataGridViewEditMode.EditProgrammatically && CurrentCellInternal.EditType is null)))
```

In general, if pattern matching is suggested by the IDE it should be used. `or` and `and` should go to the front of the line as well.

This change also adds a helper for invoking events on `DataGrid`.

Commit associated with this version was merged in September - https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn/commit/a0f63522, after the [commit](https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn/pull/69412) where the the inline arrays were introduced, which was in August.

Issues.Body:
### .NET version

9.0.100-alpha.1.23564.26

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

It works in .Net 7.0, doesn't in .Net 8.0

### Issue description

If mouse-click textBox cell in DataGridView, open AccessibilityInsight, then mouse-over DataGridView cell. It leads to AccessibilityInsight keeps loading.

**.Net 9.0/.Net 8.0: AccessibilityInsight keeps loading**
![DataGridView_AccessibilityInsightIssue](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/26474449/fb8ccacd-9d93-4f0d-9ddc-eeda7e2291b0)

**.Net 7.0: AccessibilityInsight works well**
![DataGridView_NET7 0](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/26474449/6743c7a0-1135-4be5-a728-02fb1e1f2f85)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a Winforms .Net 9.0/8.0 application
2. Add a DataGridView with TextBox cell
3. Build and run application
4. Mouse-click in DataGridView_textBox cell
5. Launch AccessibilityInsight, then mouse-over DataGridView

Issues.Title: Scaling of list type controls fails, creeps upwards in SpliContainer
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

This relates to .net **8.0**, **7.0** and **6.0**

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

There are similar issues with .Net Framework, e.g. 4.8

### Issue description


## Description
### Environment
A .Net 8.0 Forms project set for PerMonitorV2

### Issue
When moving a form with a list-type control bound by a **bottom anchor** to a splitcontainer back and forth between monitors with different scaling, it usually makes the list bottom creep upwards, (Tested with 100% versus all scale-factors from 125% to 350%).  
(Placed directly on a form, and not within a control, makes it collapse faster)

### Known workaround:
Place the list with DockStyle.Full in a dummy panel, giving the dummy panel the same size/position/anchors as the list had.

### Suspected cause
As list type controls have heights aligned with a multipla of the items, rounding errors can cause calculating the number of items there are room for to be rounded down, e.g. 10.9999 → 10, so a tiny addition to the height of say ½ or 1 pixel before dividing with the item-height and truncating might fix it.

### Here an example
A split container, and in one panel a ListBox, and a sub-panel with another ListBox filling that sub-panel
![WinFormsAppCreepingListOnRescale_workaround](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/24905467/d1e576ab-64fa-4bf5-a878-f600bfdda723)

### Code example, including the mentioned known workaround
[WinFormsAppCreepingListOnRescale_workaround_source.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/13403226/WinFormsAppCreepingListOnRescale_workaround_source.zip)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Start VS 2022 17.8
2. Create a new .Net 8.0 WinForm app
3. Make sure the proj file has
`<ApplicationHighDpiMode>PerMonitorV2</ApplicationHighDpiMode>`
4. Tools DoubleClick to add a SplitContainer, covering the whole form
5. Change the splitters Orientation to Horizontal
6. In the upper panel, ToolBox DoubleClick ListBox (just leave at default six items height)
7. Give the list a Bottom Anchor
8. Run
9. Move the app back and forth between monitors with 100% and non 100% scaling, e.g. 100% ↔ 125 %.
10. If you by a lucky punch do not see the issue, adjust the splitter slightly and retry the move
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Scaling of list type controls fails, creeps upwards in SpliContainer" (#10341)
